posts.name: Henry Wagner
posts.cooked:
I’ve been developing AprilTag alignment code using PhotonVision to calculate the robot’s ideal position for proper alignment. To move the robot to this position, I used WPILib’s Trajectory Generator.

For the most part, it works well, but I run into issues when adding rotation. Sometimes, the robot ends up about a foot off from its target, and in other cases, it moves in a completely different direction. In one instance, it even drove away from the tag instead of toward it.

Here’s a video of the issue: Video Link You can find our code here: Github Repo

link_counts.title: GitHub - ChatfieldRobotics/2025-Reefscape-Bot: Robot code for 9068's reefscape bot.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked:
Hey Henry, I was thinking about this issue and had an odd thought. How are you determining the “rotation” you need? I know PV doesn’t provide “skew” as a value, I believe it requires some sort of 3D transform, but I can not attest to that. image 893×1143 56.2 KB

image 893×1143 56.2 KB

image 893×1143 56.2 KB

posts.name: Henry Wagner
posts.cooked: Currently, the way I’m getting the skew of the April tags is via a transform 3D read from the April tag. The transform 3D has a built-in function to get the rotation that returns the skew of the tag.

posts.name: Aadit Sangvikar
posts.cooked:
Couple of things:

There are some PID terms associated with your rotation in your trajectory generator. Have you tried messing with those?

Could you graph the error in the turning PID and see if there’s any weird behavior there? I’m not sure exactly what the issue is just from the video, but there might be some odd PID stuff going on that the trajectory generator is doing.

One more idea: You might want to try logging the pose the robot thinks it’s at as it executes the command, and the pose that it thinks it ends up at. There might some discrepancy there with the odometry of the robot itself getting messed up with rotation.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: In case you weren’t aware, the WPILib trajectory generator is designed for differential drives, not swerve drives (it was written before swerve became popular). The heading is constrained to point in the same direction as the velocity vector. That assumption could be messing up your independent heading code.

posts.name: Henry Wagner
posts.cooked: I’ve been adjusting the PID values over the past few days, but they don’t seem to be the issue since the robot behaves the same way regardless of the settings. On Monday, I’ll take another video to better showcase the problem. Essentially, the robot consistently misses the target by a few feet. Additionally, when the gyro isn’t set, it sometimes moves in the wrong direction—but I’m already working on that, and I don’t believe it’s related to the targeting issue.

posts.name: Henry Wagner
posts.cooked: Hi, thanks for your response! I didn’t realize the WPILib trajectory generator was designed for differential drives. Is there a better alternative that works well with swerve?

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: There’s PathPlanner and Choreo . The former has a shallower learning curve but produces slower trajectories than Choreo. Given how simple and straight trajectories are this year, Choreo isn’t as necessary.

link_counts.title: GitHub - mjansen4857/pathplanner: A simple yet powerful path planning tool for FRC robots

posts.name: Henry Wagner
posts.cooked: Am I able to use either of these during teleop. We use path planner normally for auto, but I didn’t know that it could be used for teleop. The whole point of the trajectory generation is to make it easier on our drivers.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: Nothing is stopping you from using any of these libraries in any mode.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked: Wait, are Pathplanner and Choreo capable of on the fly path generation?  If so, how?  I was totally unaware of that option!

posts.name: Henry Wagner
posts.cooked: I just looked deeper into Pathplanner and found that it does in fact have the ability to generate paths on the fly. I’m already working on implementing right now. I’m super excited to see how this works!

link_counts.title: Create a Path On-the-fly | PathPlanner Docs
